intro: Symplocos baptica, commonly known as the sacred shrub, is a species native to the Himalayas and parts of Southeast Asia. It is a deciduous shrub that typically grows to a height of 1–3 meters, featuring small, elliptical leaves with a glossy green upper surface. The plant produces clusters of small, white flowers that bloom in late spring, followed by bright red berries in the autumn. Symplocos baptica is often found in moist, shaded areas such as forests and mountainous regions. Its botanical characteristics make it an important component of the local flora and ecosystem.
